Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Composites Based on High Bio-content, Low Toxicity, Green Matrix Resins
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will advance the development of Epoxidized Norbornylized Linseed Oil (ENLO) resin as a matrix for reinforced composites. This ENLO resin is a high bio-content, low hazard system with roughly three times the bio-content of any commercially proven resin. In Phase I feasibility was demonstrated and benefits of the system were explored. Phase II funding will be used to scale and refine the resin manufacture process and to develop and demonstrate performance of Bulk Molding Compound (BMC) and Sheet Molding Compound (SMC) utilizing the ENLO resin matrix. The research objectives are to scale the resin process to 1000-gallon reactor size, to identify a cost effective initiation system, to formulate compounds for improved fiber wetout, to characterize and benchmark performance relative to competitive molding compounds, to develop compounds and component prototypes for specific applications, and to explore enhancements to the technology that would provide a wider range of potential market segments. The anticipated technical results are the realization of cost competitive molding compounds based on the ENLO resin, the demonstration of performance in targeted initial application components, and the realization of an ENLO resin chemistry and process for the coatings market.

The broader impact / commercial potential of this project will derive from the regulatory and green benefits that customers desire to meet strengthened Environment Health and Safety (EHS) demands. The ENLO resin is derived from rapidly renewable raw material streams that can be domestically controlled, liberating the U.S. from the dependence on depleting oil reserves from unstable regions of the world and providing U.S. jobs for our farmers, plant oil processors, and resin manufacturers. Commercial composites resins include unsaturated polyesters, which contain styrene, epoxies made from Bis-phenol A, and urethanes with isocyanate. The ENLO resin contains none of these chemicals of significant EHS concern resulting in safer processes, workplaces, and products. Another major benefit of the technology is that the molded end products will sequester carbon dioxide for the life of the composite, reducing the life cycle contribution to global warming. These benefits will be magnified well beyond the scope of the $18 billion composites market because the same matrix resin can be used in the much larger $99 billion coatings market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this work was to demonstrate feasibility of a high bio-content, low toxicity, resin based on functionalized plant oils as a matrix for reinforced composites. Reinforced polymer composites are utilized in a broad array of markets, including but not limited to construction, automotive, aerospace, and consumer products. Commercial resins used include thermoset polymers such as polyesters, vinyl esters, epoxies, and urethanes. These resins are petroleum based and include chemicals of significant EH&S concern such as styrene, bisphenol A, and isocyanate. A rapidly renewable plant-based alternative will provide safer chemistries and will mitigate the growing feedstock insecurity due to depleting oil reserves and dependence on foreign oil from unstable regions of the world. This is relevant to the Phase One solicitation topic AM 8: Materials for Sustainability goals of improved sustainability, mitigation of adverse environmental impacts, and improved public health.

In Phase I the feasibility of using high bio-content, low hazard resin compositions in composites was demonstrated with the synthesis of Epoxidized Norbornylized Linseed Oil (ENLO) produced at lab scale. It was shown that these resins are particularly suitable for formulated molding compounds such as SMC and BMC. Strength and toughness were at par with unsaturated polyester resin compounds and with many engineering thermoplastic molding compounds. Phase II objectives were to drive the reaction processes up to large scale volumes for reasons to classify costs and further develop potential composite characteristics to better determine commercialization efforts.

This project unfortunately did not result in successful commercialization due to a technical issue encountered in the scale-up of the reaction. Due to unanticipated heat build-up and inability to remove it, the epoxidation reaction did not yield the desired and planned end product. The best estimates for the projected cost of the resin on a commercial scale, and of resulting finished composites using that resin, proved to be not sufficiently competitive with mainstream styrenated unsaturated polyester resins that dominate the targeted market segments today. This assessment did impact our ability to find a resin partner willing to undertake a new effort to scale up the resin during our extension period.

It is noted however, that the projected cost estimates are in the same ballpark as low-hazard monomer free resins that have recently been offered in the marketplace. Those resins are petroleum based, are free of styrene and other VOC's, and exhibit cure cycle times and end performance in the same range as the proposed ENLO resin and in the same range as many styrenated unsaturated polyester resins. Given that high cost structure relative to end properties, those monomer free alternatives have enjoyed very little penetration in the marketplace to date.

Although there are potential solutions to achieve the full reaction in a more controlled manner, the commercial pursuit of those solutions will likely remain unrealized until such time that market economics are more favorable relative to the combination of cost, environmental impact, and end performance afforded by this technology.


Last Modified: 10/29/2015
Modified by: Ryan Steiner
